Class CurveFactory

java.lang.Object
  ch.ethz.rtc.kernel.CurveFactory

public class CurveFactory
extends java.lang.Object

CurveFactory provides methods to create instances of Curve.

Method Detail

createUpperPJDCurve

public static Curve createUpperPJDCurve(long p,
                                        double j,
                                        double d,
                                        java.lang.String name)
Creates a Curve that represents the upper arrival curve of an event stream with the given period, jitter and minimum event inter-arrival distance.

The following conditions must be true for the passed parameters:

  • p >= 1
  • j >= 0
  • d >= 0

Parameters:
p - the period.
j - the jitter.
d - the minimum event inter-arrival distance.
name - the name of the created Curve.
Returns:
the upper arrival curve of an event stream with the given period, jitter and minimum event inter-arrival distance.
Throws:
java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if the parameters do not fulfill the specified conditions.

                                        double j,
                                        double d,
                                        java.lang.String name)

createUpperTDMACurve

public static Curve createUpperTDMACurve(double s,
                                         long c,
                                         double b,
                                         java.lang.String name)
Creates a Curve that represents the upper service curve of a TDMA resource with a given cycle, slot and bandwith.

The following conditions must be true for the passed parameters:

  • s >= 0 ^ s <= c
  • c >= 1
  • b >= 0

Parameters:
s - the slot length allocated to this service.
c - the cycle length of the TDMA resource.
b - the bandwidth of the TDMA resource.
name - the name of the created Curve.
Returns:
the upper service curve of a TDMA resource with the given cycle, slot and bandwidth.
Throws:
java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if the parameters do not fulfill the specified conditions.

createUpperBoundedDelayCurve

public static Curve createUpperBoundedDelayCurve(double d,
                                                 double b,
                                                 java.lang.String name)
Creates a Curve that represents the upper service curve of a bounded delay resource with a given delay and bandwidth.

Alternatively, the created Curve can also be interpreted as an ordinary two-segment curve.

In research literature, the following name substitutions are sometimes used:

  • d = Delta/2
  • b = alpha

The following conditions must be true for the passed parameters:

  • d >= 0
  • b >= 0

Parameters:
d - the delay.
b - the bandwidth of the resource.
name - the name of the created Curve.
Returns:
the upper service curve of a bounded delay resource with the given delay and bandwidth.
Throws:
java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if the parameters do not fulfill the specified conditions.

createUpperBoundedDelayCurve

public static Curve createUpperBoundedDelayCurve(Curve c)
Creates the two-segment bounded-delay curve that is an upper bound to the passed curve c.

The following conditions must be true for the passed parameters:

  • c must be wide-sense increasing

Parameters:
c - the curve.
Returns:
the two-segment bounded-delay curve that is an upper bound to the passed curve c.
Throws:
java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if the parameters do not fulfill the specified conditions.

createUpperPeriodicServiceCurve

public static Curve createUpperPeriodicServiceCurve(double s,
                                                    long p,
                                                    double b,
                                                    java.lang.String name)
Creates a Curve that represents the upper service curve of a periodic resource model with the given share, period and bandwidth.

Alternatively, the created Curve can also be interpreted as an ordinary two-segment curve.

In research literature, the following name substitutions are sometimes used:

  • s = Theta
  • p = Pi
  • b = 1

The following conditions must be true for the passed parameters:

  • s >= 0 ^ s <= p
  • p >= 1
  • b >= 0

Parameters:
s - the periodic service share slot of the resource.
p - the period of the resource.
b - the bandwidth of the resource.
name - the name of the created Curve.
Returns:
the upper service curve of a periodec service resource with the share, period and bandwidth.
Throws:
java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if the parameters do not fulfill the specified conditions.

createLowerPeriodicServiceCurve

public static Curve createLowerPeriodicServiceCurve(double s,
                                                    long p,
                                                    double b,
                                                    java.lang.String name)
Creates a Curve that represents the lower service curve of a periodic resource model with the given share, period and bandwidth.

Alternatively, the created Curve can also be interpreted as an ordinary two-segment curve.

In research literature, the following name substitutions are sometimes used:

  • s = Theta
  • p = Pi
  • b = 1

The following conditions must be true for the passed parameters:

  • s >= 0 ^ s <= p
  • p >= 1
  • b >= 0

Parameters:
s - the periodic service share slot of the resource.
p - the period of the resource.
b - the bandwidth of the resource.
name - the name of the created Curve.
Returns:
the lower service curve of a periodec service resource with the share, period and bandwidth.
Throws:
java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if the parameters do not fulfill the specified conditions.

createConservativeUpperCurveFromFiniteSampleArray

public static Curve createConservativeUpperCurveFromFiniteSampleArray(double[] samples)
(Simon Perathoner) This constructor is intended for use in SymTA/S (MPA Plugin). The array samples contains the arrival times of events in an increasing order. For instance, samples = [d1, d2, ..., dn] specifies an upper arrival curve alphau with minimum distance d1, d2, ..., dn between 1, 2, ..., n events, respectively. In other words, we have alphau^-1(1)=d1, alphau^-1(2)=d2, etc. The finite specification is extended to an infinite curve by (conservative) periodic repetition of the sampled curve part.

createConservativeLowerCurveFromFiniteSampleArray

public static Curve createConservativeLowerCurveFromFiniteSampleArray(double[] samples)
(Simon Perathoner) This constructor is intended for use in SymTA/S (MPA Plugin). The array samples contains the arrival times of events in an increasing order. For instance, samples = [d1, d2, ..., dn] specifies a lower arrival curve alphal with maximum distance d1, d2, ..., dn between 1, 2, ..., n events, respectively. In other words, we have alphal^-1(1)=d1, alphal^-1(2)=d2, etc. The finite specification is extended to an infinite curve by (conservative) periodic repetition of the sampled curve part.

createFromString

public static Curve createFromString(java.lang.String str)
Creates a Curve from a textual representation that corresponds to the command that is used in Matlab to create a Curve.

Any of the following syntax is recognized by this method: 

 name = curve(aper, per, px0, py0, period, pdy, 'name') 
 name = curve(aper, per, px0, py0, period, pdy) 
 name = curve(aper, per, px0, py0, period, 'name') 
 name = curve(aper, per, px0, py0, period) 
 name = curve(per, py0, period, pdy, 'name') 
 name = curve(per, py0, period, pdy) 
 name = curve(per, py0, period, 'name') 
 name = curve(per, py0, period) 
 name = curve(per, period, 'name') 
 name = curve(per, period)
 name = curve(aper, 'name') 
 name = curve(aper)
With the following parameters:
  • name - the name of the Curve. E.g. "A"
  • aper - the aperiodic part of the Curve, encoded as a Double[][], where every segment is represented by the triple [x0 y0 slope]. E.g. "[[0 0 0];[1 0 0.5]]"
  • per - the periodic part of the Curve, encoded as a Double[][], where every segment is represented by the triple [x0 y0 slope]. E.g. "[[0 0 0];[1 0 0.5]]"
  • period - the period of the Curve. The value of this parameters is interpreted as a Long!
  • pdy - the offset between two periodic repetidions.
  • px0 - the x-value of the start-coordinate of the periodic part
  • py0 - the y-value of the start-coordinate of the periodic part

Additionally, to the above specified syntax, any of the strings without "name = " is also recognized, e.g.:

 curve(aper, per, px0, py0, period, pdy, 'name')
If name of the curve is defined at the left side of the equal sign, as well as on the right side, then the value on the right side is taken.

Parameters:
str - the textural representation of a Curve.
Returns:
the Curve that is represented by str.
Throws:
java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if the string does not conform to the specified syntax.

importCurvesFromFile

public static java.util.HashMap<java.lang.String,Curve> importCurvesFromFile(java.lang.String filename)
                                                                      throws java.io.IOException,
                                                                             java.io.FileNotFoundException
Imports a set of Curves from a text file.

Every line in the text file must either be a comment, a blank line, or must contain a string representation of a curve that is accepted by createFromString(): 

 %Comment
 
 curveA = Curve([[0 2 2];[1 4 1];[3 6 0.5]],[[0 0 0 ];[5 0 2]], 23, 19, 7)
 curveB = Curve([[0 2 2];[1 4 1];[3 6 0.5]],[[0 0 0 ];[5 0 2]], 23, 7)
 curveC = Curve([[0 0 0 ];[5 0 2]], 7)
 curveD = Curve([[0 2 2];[1 4 1];[3 6 0.5]])

Parameters:
filename - the name of the text file
Returns:
a HashMap of Curves, with keys equalling the curve names in the text file.
Throws:
java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - - if the input of the text file does not correspond to the specification.
java.io.IOException - if I/O problems occur.
java.io.FileNotFoundException - if the text file cannot be found.

importCurveFromFile

public static Curve importCurveFromFile(java.lang.String filename)
                                 throws java.io.IOException,
                                        java.io.FileNotFoundException
Imports a Curve from a text file.

Every line in the text file must either be a comment, a blank line, or must contain a string representation of a curve that is accepted by createFromString(): 

 %Comment
 
 curveA = Curve([[0 2 2];[1 4 1];[3 6 0.5]],[[0 0 0 ];[5 0 2]], 23, 19, 7)

Parameters:
filename - the name of the text file
Returns:
the imported Curve.
Throws:
java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - - if the input of the text file does not correspond to the specification.
java.io.IOException - if I/O problems occur.
java.io.FileNotFoundException - if the text file cannot be found.

                                      java.lang.String filename)
                               throws java.io.IOException,
                                      java.io.FileNotFoundException
Exports a HashMap of Curves, such that it can be imported by importCurvesFromFile(String)

Parameters:
map - the HashMap of Curves
filename - the name of the file to which the Curves are exported
Throws:
java.io.IOException - if I/O problems occur.
java.io.FileNotFoundException - if the text file cannot be found.
